meanings.sent1: The illness seemed to emasculate him, leaving him tired and weak.
meanings.sent2: The lack of sleep can emasculate a person's ability to focus.
meanings.sent3: After a long day of work, the computer's constant crashes seemed to emasculate his patience.
meanings.sent4: The relentless heat of the desert sun emasculated the once lush green plants.
meanings.sent5: The villain's evil plan was to emasculate the hero's power, leaving him helpless.

meanings.sent1: The new regulations could emasculate the company's ability to innovate.
meanings.sent2: Lack of proper maintenance can emasculate the performance of a car.
meanings.sent3: The magician's failed trick only served to emasculate his reputation as a master illusionist.
meanings.sent4: The constant interruptions emasculated the flow of the speaker's presentation.
meanings.sent5: The harsh criticism seemed to emasculate her confidence in her artistic abilities.

meanings.definition: Remove the masculinity or male characteristics from
meanings.sent1: The costume party theme was to emasculate the men by dressing them in frilly dresses.
meanings.sent2: The evil sorcerer's curse was to emasculate the prince, turning him into a frog.
meanings.sent3: The barber's mistake seemed to emasculate the man's traditionally masculine haircut.
meanings.sent4: The strict rules of the school seemed to emasculate any sense of individuality among the students.
meanings.sent5: The toxic masculinity in the locker room conversation only served to emasculate those who didn't conform.
